item.title: Grounded Test-Time Adaptation for LLM Agents
item.description:
ğŸ“ Authors

Arthur Chen, Zuxin Liu, Jianguo Zhang, Akshara Prabhakar, Zhiwei Liu, Shelby Heinecke, Silvio Savarese, Victor Zhong, Caiming Xiong
arXiv:2511.04847 â€¢ Nov 2025 ğŸ”— https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.04847

ğŸš€ Overview

LLM-based agents can perform complex tasks like web navigation and function calling, but they often fail to generalize when deployed in new environments due to mismatches between their pre-training and the syntax (i.e., UI elements, input/output formats) and dynamics (i.e., environment transition rules) of the test-time environment. Annotated trajectories for LLM agents to learn to adapt to new environments is often not available or is too expensive to collect. This paper introduces grounded test-time adaptation (GTTA) techniques that allow agents to adapt during deployment – without annotations or expensive retraining – improving robustness and performance in unseen settings.

item.title: SynQuE: Estimating Synthetic Dataset Quality Without Annotations
item.description:
ğŸ“ Authors

Arthur Chen & Victor Zhong
arXiv:2511.03928 â€¢ Nov 2025
ğŸ”— https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.03928

ğŸš€ Overview

SynQuE (Synthetic Dataset Quality Estimation) is a framework and benchmark for ranking synthetic datasets by their expected real-world performance â€” without requiring any labeled real data.

This addresses a core bottleneck in data-scarce or privacy-sensitive settings where annotation is expensive or infeasible.

ğŸ“Œ Problem

Synthetic training data generation is widely used, but:

  • Not all synthetic datasets are equally useful
  • Larger synthetic training datasets do not guarantee better performance
  • Selecting high-quality synthetic training data without labels is still unsolved

SynQuE asks:
